awd_titl_txt: Exploring the consequences of individual differences in preschoolers' causal stance
awd_abstract_narration:
It has been increasingly recognized that promoting scientific literacy must begin early while foundational attitudes, knowledge and skills are taking shape. This project, conducted by researchers at the University of Texas and Loyola University of Chicago, will explore preschoolers' attunement to causal information -- referred to as their causal stance -- as a key component of this foundation. For example, the researchers are interested in the degree to which children seek out information about how unfamiliar objects work or can be used. By advancing our understanding of the origins and outcomes associated with the strength of children's causal stance, this project will support the development of early interventions aimed at facilitating children's participation and success in science, with a particular focus on at risk children. As such, its goals are particularly well aligned with the learning and learning environments strand of the Education and Human Resources Core Research (ECR) program. The project also has implications for professional workforce development and broadening participation in STEM fields.

This project will implement a four-year longitudinal design to address two core research goals. First, with respect to outcomes, researchers will test the hypothesis that the strength of children's causal stance at 3 years of age (measured in terms of children's preferences, as well as patterns of inquiry and exploration) is predictive of their scientific literacy and interests at 5- and 6- years of age (measured by standardized tests and surveys). Second, with respect to origins, researchers will test the hypothesis that variability in the degree to which parents talk about, and otherwise highlight, causal information (in both the laboratory and in a children's museum) relates to the strength of their children?s causal stance, as well as their longer-term scientific literacy and interests. Together, these investigations will inform discussions regarding the role of early experience in shaping scientific literacy, and relatedly, when and in what ways we might optimize children?s engagement and success in science.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we investigated potential foundations of young children’s early science-related attitudes and literacy. Specifically, we explored individual differences in preschooler’s interests in causality (i.e., their causal stance), as well as their ability to reason about this type of information. We were interested in both how aspects of the early home environment might relate to developmental variability in causal interests and reasoning, as well as how that variability might relate to emergent scientific literacy.

With respect to the former, we learned that the degree to which parents talked to their 3-year-olds about causality was related to the strength of children’s contemporaneous causal stance. This relation, however, did not carryover to later measurement timepoints. No robust relations between aspects of parent talk and developing causal reasoning skills were observed. However, aspects of the child’s early experiences at home did directly predict children’s scientific literacy. Specifically, prompting 3-year-olds to explain causal events, but not directly providing them with explanations, was associated with higher scientific literacy scores both concurrently and one year later. Measures of the child’s broader exposure to science at home were even more robust predictors. The frequency with which parents engaged with their 3-year-olds in science related activities was associated with scientific literacy through first grade, as well as growth throughout this period. The amount of science-related materials (e.g., books, apps, toys) available in the home was less predictive.

Interestingly, both children’s causal stance, and aspects of their causal reasoning skills, also uniquely predicted scientific literacy. Specifically, children’s causal stance at 3 years of age predicted scientific literacy at each subsequent wave of data collection, extending through preschool, kindergarten, and into first grade. In addition, a cluster of three causal reasoning measures related stably to each other from 3 to 5 years of age and was consistently related to scientific literacy throughout this developmental period. Not only were these constructs correlated with each other concurrently at each age tested, but each predicted the other in subsequent years.

These and related findings have thus far been presented in three published manuscripts and eight conference presentations. Two more manuscripts are under review, and two more are in preparation. Broad dissemination to parents, teachers and informal educators has, and will continue to be, assured through community outreach and longstanding partnerships. The project has also provided research experience and training to many students from diverse backgrounds at both the undergraduate and graduate level.

In sum, this project reveals how the roots of scientific literacy are taking hold even before children begin formal education. The results specifically highlight the potential of intervening early (i.e., before school entry), targeting children’s causal stance (in addition to scientific knowledge and reasoning skills), and embracing parents (in addition to teachers) in efforts towards bolstering children’s early scientific literacy and better preparing them for long-term success in school.
